Template.phase_banner: This is a new service - your <feedback>feedback</feedback> will help us to improve it.

nsoc.title: National Space Operations Centre Warning and Protection Services
nsoc.content: National Space Operations Centre (NSpOC) Warning and Protection Services support UK and international partners to manage space risks and hazards.

list_items.statistics: Explore key statistics for UK space hazards

new_users.title: New users
new_users.markup:
We provide monthly reports on space risks and hazards which are accessible to everyone (National Space Operations Centre) and regularly updated space weather information is available from our partner the Met Office.

At this time, access to the operational services provided by Monitor Space Hazards is available to UK licensed satellite operators and UK Government departments. If you meet these criteria and would like access, please contact monitorspacehazards@ukspaceagency.gov.uk.

Visit National Space Operations Centre for further information about our services.

Dashboard.title: National Space Operations Centre Warning and Protection Services
Dashboard.content: National Space Operations Centre (NSpOC) Warning and Protection Services support UK and international partners to manage space risks and hazards.

view_roadmap.title: View Monitor Space Hazards roadmap
view_roadmap.description: Roadmap for current and future service developments.

support_and_guidance.description: Support and guidance for all active services.

Terms_and_conditions.label: I have read and agreed to the Terms and Conditions

Contact_analyst.title: Contact a UKSA orbital analyst
Contact_analyst.content:
UKSA orbital analysts are available Monday to Sunday, 8am to 4pm (except public holidays). Your message will be triaged and an analyst will get back to you as soon as possible.

UKSA orbital analysts can provide:

Further detail on their calculationsAn indication on whether further analysis of an event is possible

UKSA orbital analysts cannot provide:

Advice on how you should manoeuvre your satelliteAnalysis on a planned manoeuvre
Contact_analyst.event_id: Conjunction event ID or Re-entry event ID

Send.title: Your message has been sent to a UKSA orbital analyst.
Send.content: Your message will be triaged and an analyst will get back to you as soon as possible.

Credentials.title: Credentials for API authentication
Credentials.warning: Copy your Client ID and Client Secret to authenticate with the API. Do not share your credentials.

Event_notification_thresholds_settings.title: Set your conjunction event notification thresholds
Event_notification_thresholds_settings.content:
We will send you notifications when the probability of collision, total miss distance and mean radial miss distance meets threshold and the time to conjunction event is below the threshold you have set.

You are responsible for the safe operation of your satellites and should choose settings which allow you to do this.

The default settings are examples of thresholds, not recommendations.

Notification_settings.title: Choose your notification settings
Notification_settings.content:
New event notifications will be collated and sent in one email and/or SMS every 12 hours.

Choose which notifications you wish to receive. Uncheck boxes where you do not wish to receive notifications.

Add_new_user.title: Add a new user
Add_new_user.content: Add a new user to join your organisation by entering the details below. New users will receive an invitation to the email address specified.

Incident_banners.title: Manage incident banners
Incident_banners.content:
In the case of an incident, the Monitor Space Hazards service will remain live, but it is important to notify all Monitor Space Hazards users.

Super users are able to display banners that will be visible at the top of each page, warning users that the information presented on Monitor Space Hazards may not be accurate.

Analysis_upload_log.title: UKSA analysis uploads
Analysis_upload_log.description: View all UKSA analysis uploaded to Monitor Space Hazards for UK conjunction events.

help.title: Help with this table
help.description1: Select the file to view the analysis.
help.description2: Select delete to permanently remove the analysis from the service.

Manoeuvre_support_upload_log.title: Manoeuvre support uploads
Manoeuvre_support_upload_log.description: View all Manoeuvre support files uploaded to Monitor Space Hazards for UK conjunction events.

help.title: Help with this table
help.description1: Select the file to view the manoeuvre support.
help.description2: Select delete to permanently remove the file from the service.

Distribution_lists.title: View distribution lists
Distribution_lists.description: We will send notifications according to the distribution lists outlined on this page.

conjunctions_help.content:
Standard conjunction alert

There are various criteria which determine if alerts are produced about conjunction events. These criteria vary by type of object.

For UK-licensed objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest ApproachMore than 0.1% probability of collisionPress interest

For non-UK objects:

Less than 5 days until Time of Closest Approach, with:Low risk or higherNo manoeuvre expected

For all objects:

If nominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority conjunction alert

For UK-licensed objects:

More than 1% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expected

For non-UK objects:

More than 5% probability of collisionNo manoeuvre expectedSignificant press interest

reentry_help.content:
Standard re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a standard re-entry alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (UK Space Agency, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority) and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a priority re-entry alert, then it has been distributed more widely across UK devolved and central government departments.

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

Satellite_ephemeris_upload.title: Uploading your ephemeris data
Satellite_ephemeris_upload.content:
If you would like updated UKSA analysis on this conjunction event using your ephemeris data, attach a file below.

If upload is successful, the file will be renamed with the timestamp of the creation date and made available from the Ephemeris table on the satellite information page.

Upload a CCSDS .oem file. The file must not exceed 20MB.
Satellite_ephemeris_upload.help_summary: More information about sharing your ephemerises with the UKSA
Satellite_ephemeris_upload.help_content:
Additional analysis will be provided by UKSA orbital analysts only on conjunction events that UKSA analysis determines breach a probability of collision ≥ 10-5

View the terms and conditions for data handling information

Success.title: Ephemeris upload complete
Success.content: Your ephemeris for {noradId} has been successfully uploaded to Monitor Space Hazards

Conjunctions.title: Track conjunction events (Monitor your satellites)
Conjunctions.description: This table shows upcoming conjunction events involving UK-licensed satellites by default. You can apply filters to view past events.

search_bar.label: Find a conjunction event:
search_bar.placeholder: Search by event or object ID

help1.title: Help with this table
help1.content:
This service tracks conjunction events for UK-licensed objects.

Conjunction alerts: conjunction events that meet the UK Space Agency's thresholds for alerting UK governmentAll conjunction events: all conjunction events, including those which have not met alerting thresholds, either for a specific operator or all UK-licensed satellites

help2.title: Help with this table
help2.content:
This table shows upcoming conjunction events involving UK-licensed satellites by default. You can apply filters to view past events.

Select the event ID to view more information

Each event ID or row represents one conjunction event including all related Conjunction Data Messages (CDMs) and UKSA analysis.

The your interest column contains HIGH labels for events that meet your thresholds for notifications.

help.title: Help with this chart
help.content:
Data sources can be turned on or off by selecting the series in the legend below the chart.

Evolution of operational conjunction event data is displayed as a continuous line. Individual Special ephemeris probabilities can be turned on or off.

You can reveal more details about a specific data point by moving your mouse over it or tapping on the data point on touch-enabled screens.

Full conjunction event data can be viewed or downloaded from Conjunction event history.

help.title: Help with this chart
help.content:
Miss distances can be turned on or off by selecting the series in the legend below the chart.

Evolution of operational conjunction event data is displayed as a continuous line. Individual Special ephemeris probabilities can be turned on or off.

You can reveal more details about a specific data point by moving your mouse over it or tapping on the data point on touch-enabled screens.

Full conjunction event data can be viewed or downloaded from Conjunction event history.

additional_object_summary.title: Additional object data
additional_object_summary.content:
ESA DISCOS provides additional object data where available. Contact ESA DISCOS if your satellite data is incorrect.

ESA DISCOS data was last updated on: {updateTime} UTC

Object_data.title: Object Data
Object_data.space_track: Space-Track is the main source of object data. Contact Space-Track if your satellite data is incorrect.

help.title: Help with this table
help.content:
Historical CDMs for the event are available in this table. Information about the individual CDM is available, including the calculation method for the probability of collision, the position uncertainty and data source for each object.

The data source for each object either comes from SSN observations, special or operational owner/operator ephemeris or NASA/CARA. Further information about these can be found in definitions on data sources.

Further_information.title: Further information
Further_information.description: To understand more about how this data was generated by the UKSA, see:
Further_information.link2: Help with the information on this page

Reentries.title: Track re-entry events
Reentries.content: This table contains all tracked re-entry events, including re-entry events that meet the UK Space Agency's thresholds for alerting UK government. For further detail on how risk and alert thresholds are defined, see 'Help with this table' below.

Event_summary.title: Re-entry event summary
Event_summary.contact_analyst: Contact the UK Space Agency for more information

Further_information.content: To understand more about how this data was generated by the UKSA, see:
Further_information.help_with_information: Help with the information on re-entry events

Reentry_alert.notification_banner: You are able to <edit>edit this alert</edit> or <send>send this alert to additional recipients</send>
Reentry_alert.title: Re-entry alert for {objectName}

accordion.potential_impact_overseas_territory: Potential impact by British Overseas Territory

Executive_summary.title: Executive summary
Executive_summary.content: The UK Space Agency is tracking the upcoming re-entry of an object from space into the Earth's atmosphere, posing a potential threat to life and property on the ground. All re-entered debris should be considered as hazardous until proven otherwise.

Map.see_further_information: See Further information for more detail on methodology used in this report and the organisations that have been sent this alert.

Next_update.title: Next update
Next_update.content: For Low Risk events, updates are only sent if the event breaches a higher risk threshold. For Medium and High Risk events, updates are sent as soon as new information is available. A close-down report will be sent in all cases.
Next_update.contact_analyst: Contact the UK Space Agency for more information

immediate_response.title: Immediate response
immediate_response.content:
All re-entered debris should be considered as hazardous until proven otherwise. The most commonly used hazardous materials used on spacecraft are:

HydrazineKerosene

Debris objects should not be disposed of nor made available to the public. An appropriate hazmat response (i.e testing by fire service) should take place first.

The UK Space Agency is responsible for the monitoring of re-entry of objects from space into Earth's atmosphere, providing warnings and alerts across HM Government. UKSA will act as subject matter experts, providing advice and guidance on how to deal with the incident. This includes coordinating public communications about the event.

In the event of debris from the re-entry surviving to the ground, local authorities are responsible for any incident response and should follow standard response activities for the damage caused using existing Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (CBRN) and/or plane crash policies.

Cabinet Office will take on the lead for incident response coordination if the impacts are significant or are across multiple sectors.

recovery_and_clean_up.title: Recovery and clean up
recovery_and_clean_up.content:
Decontamination: If the object is contaminated with hazardous material, it should be decontaminated. Decontamination is led by Defra who are the Lead Government Department for decontamination in England, in liaison with local authorities.

Storage: The object should be sent to storage by a specialist supplier in the local area, as agreed and organised by Defra.

Release: If the object has been declared safe (by Defra), UKSA will direct it's release to either: MOD Defence Intelligence if the object is of Chinese or Russian origin; the owner of the object or the state liable for the object, organised via the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office; or the Air Accident Investigation Bureau or the Civil Aviation Authority if the object is UK-licensed.

Disposal: If the object cannot be declared safe or decontaminated, it should disposed of as per standard procedures held by Defra.

Incident close down: When departments agree that recovery can be handled through Business As Usual structures, the incident can be closed down. The UK Space Agency and Cabinet Office will confirm close down of the event to all parties involved.

Liability_for_damages.content: {licenseCountry} is liable for any damages and associated costs of the response and recovery efforts caused by the re-entry under the terms of the 1972 Space Liability Convention.

Press_attention.empty: We have not seen any press attention on this event.

Risk_thresholds.content: Risk thresholds are calculated according to the probability of the object re-entering over the UK.
Risk_thresholds.probability_of_reentry: Probability of re-entry over the UK (%)

standard_alert.title: Standard re-entry alert
standard_alert.content:
If this report is classified as a standard re-entry alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (UK Space Agency, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority) and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

priority_alert.title: Priority re-entry alert
priority_alert.content:
If this report is classified as a priority re-entry alert, then it has been distributed more widely across UK devolved and central government departments.

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)>UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

Further_information.help_with_information: Help with the information on re-entry events

Reentry_alert_edit.title: Re-entry alert for {objectName}
Reentry_alert_edit.content:
If edits or additions are needed to the automatically generated report, these can be made through free text inputs in the boxes below. Once published, these edits will automatically be added to the relevant event page, and users on the appropriate distribution lists will be notified of the update.

The below boxes can only process plain text. Do not include images or text formatting.
Reentry_alert_edit.review_description: Free text edits to re-entry event {shortId}

banner.title: Ensure you review before publishing.
banner.content: It is advised that at least two individuals review text edits before they are published on GOV.UK platforms.

Reentry_alert_send.title: Send alert to additional recipients
Reentry_alert_send.content:
This page shows you the current distribution status of the re-entry alert and allows you to manually distribute the alert to additional recipients.

If it is not already, you can choose to make the alert a priority re-entry alert. You are also able to manually select individual emails to send the alert to.

alert_criteria_help.title: Distribution lists and re-entry alert criteria
alert_criteria_help.content:
Distribution lists:

You are able to view which distribution list users are currently on in the account section (View distribution lists)

Standard re-entry alert

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority re-entry alert:

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

information_on_calculations.title: Information on calculations
information_on_calculations.content:
Probability of collision values will differ depending on the object sizes and methods used in calculations.

Space-Track uses a radius of 1m, 3m or 5m in their probability calculations. UKSA orbital analysis uses information on object sizes from ESA DISCOS or a custom value if suitable.

help.title: Help with this table
help.content:
This service tracks all upcoming re-entry events worldwide, including those which pose a risk to the UK. The service reports on two types of re-entry event.

Upcoming re-entry alerts: all upcoming re-entry events that meet the UK Space Agency's thresholds for alerting UK governmentUpcoming re-entry events worldwide: all upcoming re-entry events worldwide, including those which have not met alerting thresholds

Add_new_user.success_message:
User has been added to {organisation}.

They will be sent an invitation email to the address provided to finish setting up their account.
Add_new_user.success_message_only_admins: You can edit the new user's settings to select the notifications they receive.
Add_new_user.select_account_type_hint: What type of access will this user require to Monitor Space Hazards?
Add_new_user.help_content:
Admins can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site. Administrators can also view all user accounts for an organisation, and can add new users, and change or delete existing users.

Operators can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site.

Users can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them.

help.title: What can these accounts do?
help.adminsDescription: can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site. Administrators can also view all user accounts for an organisation, and can add new users, and change or delete existing users.
help.operatorsDescription: can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them, and can upload ephemeris data to the site.
help.usersDescription: can view information on their organisation's satellites and the upcoming conjunction events involving them.

help_reentry.title: Criteria for priority re-entry alerts
help_reentry.content:
Standard re-entry alert

If this report is classified as a standard re-entry alert, then it has been distributed only to key UK government organisations (UK Space Agency, Ministry of Defence, Cabinet Office, Civil Aviation Authority) and international partners.

The criteria for producing a standard re-entry alert is less than 36 hours until re-entry and one of the following:

Any “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with overflights of the UK mainlandAny “large” object in US SATCAT (except designed for demise) with more than 0.1% chance of impact in overseas territoriesAny UK-licensed object (except designed for demise)Press interestNominated for escalation by the National Space Operations Centre

Priority re-entry alert

The criteria for producing a priority re-entry alert is debris likely to survive to the ground and one of the following:

More than 0.1% chance of impact in the UK (and overseas territories on case by case basis)UK-licensed objectSignificant press interest

Edit_alert.hint: This text will appear under paragraphs which read:

Include details of any press attention related to this event. Leave blank if there has been no press attention.

This text will appear alongside a link to standard UK Space Agency press lines.

Send_alert.title: Send alert to additional recipients
Send_alert.content:
This page shows you the current distribution status of the {type} alert and allows you to manually distribute the alert to additional recipients.

If it is not already, you can choose to make the alert a priority {type} alert. You are also able to manually select individual emails to send the alert to.

Change_distribution.individually_selected_recipients_label: Provide individual email addresses to receive alerts about this event in the box below. Separate each email address with a semi-colon.

Review.title: Review your alert before sending
Review.hint: Ensure that all the appropriate individuals and government agencies have been selected before sending alerts. The button below will send alerts automatically.
